claim: The European Union has 27 member countries as of 2025

supporting.text: The European Union officially lists 27 member countries on its official website as of 2025.

attacks.text: The European Union officially lists 27 member countries on its official website as of 2025.
The official website may not have been updated to reflect recent changes in membership status.
The EU maintains real-time updates for membership status, and delays in updates are highly unlikely.
Some countries may be in the process of leaving or joining the EU, creating ambiguity in the official count.
EU accession or withdrawal processes are publicly documented and take years, making real-time ambiguity unlikely.

supporting.text: Following the departure of the United Kingdom in 2020, the EU has consistently maintained 27 member states.

attacks.text: Following the departure of the United Kingdom in 2020, the EU has consistently maintained 27 member states.
Some countries, such as Montenegro or Serbia, are in active accession negotiations and could join the EU before 2025, increasing the number of member states.
Accession negotiations typically take many years, and it is unlikely that any new country will complete the process by 2025.
Political instability or referendums in existing member states could lead to additional departures, reducing the number of member states below 27.
The EU has strengthened its cohesion mechanisms since Brexit, making further departures unlikely in the near term.

supporting.text: No new countries were admitted to the EU between 2020 and 2025, keeping the total at 27.

attacks.text: No new countries were admitted to the EU between 2020 and 2025, keeping the total at 27.
The EU's expansion policy is dynamic, and negotiations with candidate countries could conclude before 2025, increasing membership.
Historical trends show EU expansion negotiations typically take longer than 5 years, making new admissions by 2025 unlikely.
A member country could leave the EU by 2025, reducing the total below 27.
EU treaties and political stability make member exits highly improbable in the short term.

supporting.text: Official EU treaties and agreements signed in 2025 reference 27 member states.

attacks.text: Official EU treaties and agreements signed in 2025 reference 27 member states.
Some treaties may use outdated or aspirational language without reflecting actual membership changes.
EU treaties are legally binding documents that must accurately reflect the current membership status.
The claim doesn't account for potential withdrawals or suspensions that may have occurred in 2025 but weren't yet reflected in treaties.
EU membership changes are highly publicized events that would be immediately reflected in official documents.

supporting.text: The European Commission, the EU's executive body, operates with representation from 27 member countries as of 2025.

attacks.text: The European Commission, the EU's executive body, operates with representation from 27 member countries as of 2025.
The European Commission's representation does not necessarily reflect the exact number of member countries, as some countries may have temporary suspensions or special arrangements.
The EU's official treaties and membership lists confirm 27 member countries as of 2025, with no suspensions or special arrangements affecting this count.

supporting.text: EU budgetary and legislative processes in 2025 involve contributions and votes from 27 member states.

attacks.text: EU budgetary and legislative processes in 2025 involve contributions and votes from 27 member states.
The EU has expanded to include new member states beyond 27 in 2025, such as candidate countries like Albania or Montenegro.
Official EU accession processes take years, and no new members were confirmed to join by 2025.
Some EU member states may have withdrawn or suspended participation in budgetary processes by 2025.
No formal withdrawals or suspensions of EU membership occurred by 2025, as confirmed by official EU treaties and announcements.
